item.itunes:subtitle: Friday, January 17, 2014, 9 - 11 p.m.

item.title: 24 Hours of Radio Art: Meat Hands "Instilling Fear in the Fearless"
item.description: Meat Hands invites all listeners to conduct a sustained observation, with ears as eyes, in order to appreciate the various rhythm and tones of their world, both natural and synthetic. By comparing these various textures, the listener will develop an understanding, and passion for the rhythm of life. In this way the motors and machines of cities can be consciously attuned, so that every sound is transformed into an intoxicating orchestra of noises. Listeners may at last hear without fear. https://soundcloud.com/meathandshttp://www.youtube.com/user/Smacproductions2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Friday, January 17, 2014, from 7 - 9 p.m.

item.title: The Student Leadership Conference 2014 Live Broadcast of David Ng
item.description:
David Ng AMBL Director and Senior Instructor, UBC Terry Project co-leader
David Ng is a geneticist, science literacy academic, writer, and faculty based at the Michael Smith Laboratories at the University of British Columbia. You can find out more about his science literacy activities at http://thisishowitalkscience.tumblr.com and you can follow him on twitter @ng_dave
Of note: (1) he is partly responsible for the massive DNA helix emblazoned on his buildings facade; (2) his Dad beat up Bruce Lee; (3) his first foray into general publishing featured a unicorn on the front cover; and (4) his wife and kids are all exemplary. He has also set uppopperfont.net as his personal blog: this is where he categorizes funny, curious, pretty things that work well as a break or transition in that science talk youre about to give
item.itunes:subtitle: Saturday, January 11, 2014 from 3-4 p.m.

item.title: The Student Leadership Conference 2014 Live Broadcast of Alia Dharamsi
item.description:
Alia Dharamsi Outstanding Future Alumna Award winner & passionate philantropist
Ms. Dharamsi is a fourth year medical student at UBC, with a background in International Health. She aspires for a diverse career including her interests in global health, addictions and mental health, urban poverty, and rural medicine. She has worked in Vancouvers Downtown Eastside for over eight years, on health projects in rural communities throughout BC, and on educational initiatives in Central America. She aspires to use social media and technological innovation in medical education, to bring critical care resources to remote communities only otherwise accessible by air or sea. In her spare time shes an avid runner and swimmer, and can usually be found on the trails or in the lakes of BCs great outdoors.
item.itunes:subtitle: Saturday, January 11, 2014 from 10:30 - 11:20 a.m.

item.title: Fundrive! with Sarah C March 3, 3-4pm
2013 UBC First Nations House of Learning Idle No More Teach-in, February 1, 1-3 p.m.
item.description:
Host: Dr. Linc Kesler Panelists: Dr. Gordon Christie Dr. Glen Coulthard Dr. Shelly Johnson Dr. Dory Nason
The UBC First Nations House of Learning is hosted an Idle No More Teach-in at Sty-Wet-Tan, the great hall of the First Nations Longhouse, on the traditional, ancestral, unceded territory of the Musqueam people.
http://aboriginal.ubc.ca/2013/01/24/idle-no-more-teach-in/
Distinguished Aboriginal faculty provided a background on the movement, outlined the aspects of Bills 38 and 45 that are seen as problematic and discussed ways that classroom dialogue around this issue can be incorporated in an informed and productive way. Everyone was welcome, including students, staff, faculty, TAs and community members - and people packed the place! CiTR was thankful to be part of this event, helping to bring it to listeners who couldn't attend in person.
item.itunes:subtitle: UBC First Nations Longhouse (Sty-Wet-Tan) 1985 West Mall

item.title: The Amelie: Canadian Refugee Policy and the Story of the 1987 Boat People
item.description:
This documentary features interviews with the refugees who were passengers aboard the Amelie, lawyers, policy experts, academics and activists to tell the story of the Amelie and offer multiple perspectives on current and past events.
Funded by the Community Radio Fund of Canada with support from CKDU.
Thank You: CRFC, CKDU 88.1FM, The Nova Scotia Public Interest Research Group, The Maritime Sikh Society, Pierre Loiselle, David Parker, Erica Butler, Avtar Sandhu, Jagpal Tiwana, Vernon Malone and everyone else who was interviewed.
Musical Excerpts: Punjabi Folk music by Surinder Kour and Parkash Kour. "Where We Belong" by LAL, from the album Deportation. Used with Permission. "Le Vent Marin" by Gianna Lauren from the album Some Move Closer, Some Move On. Used with Permission.
Co-produced by Ella Bedard and Jane Kirby
item.itunes:subtitle: 174 refugees from India land in Nova Scotia and meet an unwelcoming Canadian government

item.title: Green College Principal's Series: Craig Jones with "Trying Polygamy"
item.description:
Principal's Series: Thinking at the Edge of Reason / Interdisciplinarity in Action.
TRYING POLYGAMY: THE ISSUES AND OUTCOME OF REFERENCE RE: S.293 OF THE CRIMINAL CODE OF CANADA. Lecturer: Craig Jones, Constitutional & Administrative Law, BC Ministry of Justice. Coach House, Green College, UBC. April 10, 2012 5:00 pm - 6:30 pm
The recent polygamy reference case in the BC Supreme Court took 44 days of hearing, and had scores of witnesses, expert and individual, from all over North America. In the end, the Chief Justice declared that he had before him the most comprehensive judicial record on the subject ever produced, and held that polygamys harms outweighed the religious freedoms of the practices adherents. Craig Jones, lead counsel for the Attorney General of British Columbia (and a Green College Society Member) explains the unprecedented courtroom struggle over the constitutionality of s.293, Canadas polygamy law, and the challenge of proving polygamys harms in the age of religious and sexual liberty.
item.itunes:subtitle: Details at http://www.greencollege.ubc.ca/
